oai_dc:dc.dc:title: LeMoyne Normal Institute Graduating Class
Lemoyne Owen College Graduating Class
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Schools
African American college students; African American universities and colleges
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Graduation portrait showing twenty-six men and women wearing cap and gown, lined up in five rows, posed on the steps against turned columns and decorative woodwork on the porch of a frame building.

In 1870, Dr. Francis J. LeMoyne, a Pennsylvania doctor and abolitionist, donated $20,000 to the American Missionary Association to build an elementary and secondary school for prospective teachers. This portait of men and women wearing graduation regalia, includes LeMoyne Normal Institute's first principal: Professor L.T. Larsen, standing to the right of front row.
